keyTakeAways: A man who sexually assaulted a college student in 2013 sent a Facebook message saying 'So I raped you' years later, which prompted the victim to renew her efforts to seek justice.
The case underscores the systemic failure in campus sexual assault cases, where victims often face delays, lack of prosecution, and destruction of evidence.
The victim, Shannon Keeler, spent over a decade pursuing justice, and the case ultimately resulted in a sentence below state guidelines due to the defendant’s guilty plea and remorse.

Ian Cleary, who had lived in the U.S. and worked for Tesla before moving overseas, was extradited from France after being detained on a vagrancy charge, highlighting the difficulty of tracking down perpetrators of campus crimes.

The judge acknowledged the emotional trauma of the crime and emphasized that the defendant’s admission of guilt and remorse were key factors in the sentence, even though the crime had gone undetected for over a decade.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In 2013, Ian Cleary sexually assaulted Shannon Keeler at Gettysburg College. For over a decade, the case remained unresolved due to a lack of prosecution and the destruction of evidence. In 2019, Cleary sent a Facebook message saying 'So I raped you', prompting Keeler to renew her efforts. After a three-year search, Cleary was extradited from France in 2024, where he had been detained on a vagrancy charge. At a sentencing hearing in October 2025, he was given a two to four-year prison sentence, below state guidelines, due to his guilty plea, remorse, and history of mental illness. Keeler, who has spent 12 years pursuing justice, described the case as a turning point where the justice system finally delivered accountability — though at a personal and emotional cost. The case highlights broader systemic failures in campus sexual assault investigations, including prosecutorial reluctance and loss of evidence.
title: Man Sentenced to Prison After Facebook Message of 'So I Raped You' Years After 2013 College Assault
